title: Food Preparation — Celery and Peanut Butter
description: The child washes celery, cuts it into sticks, and fills them with peanut butter. This multi-step food preparation builds sequencing skills and independence.
instructions:
1. Wash hands together.
2. Show the celery. 'First we wash it under water.'
3. Place on the cutting board. Demonstrate cutting into sticks with a child-safe knife.
4. Scoop peanut butter with a small spreader and fill the celery channel.
5. Optional: add raisins on top ('ants on a log').
6. Enjoy the snack and clean up all materials.
materials_needed: Peanut butter or sunflower seed butter

slides.setup_instructions: Wash hands. Arrange all materials on a tray. Pre-wash the celery if needed.

slides.text: 'Today we are making a special snack with three steps: wash, cut, and spread!'
Step 1: Wash the celery under running water. Pat dry. Step 2: Place on the cutting board and cut into sticks.
Step 3: Use the spreader to scoop peanut butter. Fill the groove in the celery. 'The groove is like a little boat!'
Optional: place raisins on top. 'These are called ants on a log! The celery is the log, and the raisins are the ants.'

slides.prompt: Prepare 3-4 celery sticks on your own. Follow all three steps: wash, cut, spread. Add raisins if you like!

slides.text: Enjoy your snack! Wash the cutting board, knife, and spreader. Wipe down your workspace.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete all three preparation steps independently?

parent_notes: This is a multi-step food preparation activity that builds sequencing and executive function skills. Substitute sunflower seed butter for nut-free households. The 'ants on a log' variation is motivating for young children. Let the child serve their creation to family members — serving others builds pride and social awareness.

title: Moveable Alphabet — Building CVC Words from Dictation
description: The child builds CVC words with the moveable alphabet as the adult slowly dictates them. This is the beginning of spelling from sound.
instructions:
1. 'I am going to say a word, and you will build it with the moveable alphabet.'
2. Say 'bed' slowly: /b/-/e/-/d/. Repeat naturally: 'bed.'
3. Child segments the sounds and finds each letter.
4. Say the next word: 'hop.' Then 'fun.' Then 'wig.' Then 'red.'
5. If the child struggles, say the word more slowly or help isolate the middle vowel.
6. Child reads each word back after building.

slides.setup_instructions: Open the moveable alphabet. Clear a large work space for building multiple words.

slides.text: 'Today I will say words and you will build them! Listen carefully to each sound in the word.'
Say 'bed' naturally. 'What sounds do you hear?' If needed, stretch it: /b/-/e/-/d/. Child finds b, e, d.
Continue with: hop, fun, wig, red, mug. Give the child time to think about each sound.
After building each word, child reads it back. 'You wrote it AND you can read it!'

slides.prompt: Build 5 words from dictation. Then choose 2 words and draw a picture for each one.

slides.text: 'You are writing words from just hearing them! Your ears hear the sounds and your hands build the words.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build at least 3 out of 5 dictated CVC words?

parent_notes: Dictation is the bridge between encoding (spelling) and decoding (reading). The child must hear the word, segment it into sounds, and find the matching letters. The middle vowel sound is often the hardest to isolate. If the child writes 'bed' as 'bd,' they are hearing the consonants but missing the vowel — this is developmentally normal. Help by stretching the vowel: 'b-eeee-d.'

title: Linear Counting — 1 to 20
description: The child practices counting objects in a line from 1 to 20, connecting one-to-one correspondence with the newly learned teen numbers.
instructions:
1. Set out 20 small objects in a long line.
2. Count together, touching each: 1, 2, 3... up to 20.
3. The child counts independently.
4. Practice cardinality: 'How many are there in all?' (20)
5. 'Give me 14.' Child counts out 14.
6. 'Give me 17.' Continue with various teen numbers.
materials_needed: Counting mat or long strip of paper

slides.setup_instructions: Line up 20 objects in a row. Have numeral cards available.

slides.text: 'Let's count all the way to 20! Touch each object as we count together.'
Count slowly together: '1, 2, 3... 10, 11, 12... 20!' Touch each object exactly once.
'How many objects are there altogether?' (20) 'The last number you say is the TOTAL.'
Place numeral cards next to groups: 'Here is the card for 10. Here is 15. Here is 20.'

slides.prompt: 'Give me 14!' Count out 14 objects. 'Give me 17!' Continue with different teen numbers.

slides.text: 'You can count to 20! And you can count out ANY number up to 20!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child count to 20 with one-to-one correspondence and count out specific quantities?

parent_notes: Linear counting to 20 bridges the gap between rote counting (saying the numbers) and rational counting (understanding quantity). The 'give me' game tests whether the child truly understands what teen numbers mean. If the child counts out 14 correctly, they understand that 14 is a specific quantity. Practice counting objects in daily life: stairs, toys, grapes, books.

title: Puzzle Map — North America
description: Introduction to the North America puzzle map. The child learns the names and locations of the countries within North America.
instructions:
1. Present the North America puzzle map.
2. 'This is the continent where we live! Let's learn about the countries inside it.'
3. Remove the United States piece. 'This is the United States.' Replace it.
4. Remove Canada: 'This is Canada — our neighbor to the north.'
5. Remove Mexico: 'Mexico is our neighbor to the south.'
6. Introduce 2-3 Central American countries or Caribbean islands.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the North America map on a table. Have the world map nearby for context.

slides.text: Show North America on the world map: 'This is the continent where we live. Now let's look INSIDE it!'
Remove the United States: 'This is the United States — it's where we live!' Discuss its shape. Replace it.
Remove Canada: 'Canada is very big! It's north of us.' Remove Mexico: 'Mexico is south of us.'
Introduce Guatemala or Cuba if the child is interested. 'North America has many countries!'

slides.prompt: Take out the three big countries. Can you put them back? Name each one as you place it.

slides.text: 'You know the countries of North America! United States, Canada, and Mexico.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and place the three main North American countries?

parent_notes: Moving from the world map to a continent map zooms in on detail. The child learns that continents contain countries. Focus on the three largest countries first. If your family has connections to other North American countries, feature those as well. Puzzle maps build spatial awareness and fine motor skills through the knob-grasping.

title: Read-Aloud: The Ugly Vegetables by Grace Lin
description: Reading 'The Ugly Vegetables' by Grace Lin, a story about a girl who helps her mother plant a Chinese vegetable garden that looks different from the neighbors' flower gardens.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What do you see growing here? Do these look like regular gardens?'
2. Read aloud with warmth — the narrator's initial embarrassment and ultimate pride.
3. Discuss: 'Why was she embarrassed at first? What changed her mind?'
4. Talk about different kinds of beauty — flowers are pretty, but vegetables become delicious soup.
5. Discuss cultural foods: 'What special foods does your family make?'
6. Connect to diversity: different isn't ugly, it's wonderful.
materials_needed: The Ugly Vegetables by Grace Lin
Optional: vegetables from the story to examine

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: The Ugly Vegetables by Grace Lin

items: Optional: Chinese vegetables to see and touch
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready in a comfortable reading spot.

slides.text: Cover: 'This garden looks different from the other gardens on the street. Let's find out why!'
Read with expression — show the contrast between the pretty flower gardens and the 'ugly' vegetable garden.
Discuss: 'Why did the girl think her garden was ugly? What happened when the soup was ready? How did the neighbors react?'

slides.prompt: Draw two gardens side by side — a flower garden and a vegetable garden. Which one can you eat? What vegetables would you plant?

slides.text: 'The vegetables weren't ugly at all — they were delicious! Sometimes the best things look different from what we expect.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why the 'ugly' vegetables turned out to be wonderful?

parent_notes: This story celebrates cultural diversity, gardening, and the idea that beauty comes in many forms. Grace Lin's autobiographical story introduces Chinese vegetables and cooking. It connects to Montessori themes of respect for cultures, food preparation, and nature study. The recipe at the back of the book can be a cooking activity.

title: Baric Tablets — Introduction
description: Introduction to the Montessori baric tablets. The child discriminates between tablets of different weights using only the sense of touch with a blindfold.
instructions:
1. Present three sets of baric tablets: light (balsa), medium (maple), heavy (walnut).
2. Hold one light and one heavy tablet. 'Feel the difference? One is light and one is heavy.'
3. Three-period lesson: 'This is light. This is heavy. Which is heavier?'
4. Introduce the medium tablet.
5. Blindfold the child. Hand them tablets one at a time to sort by weight.
6. Sort all tablets into three groups: light, medium, heavy.
materials_needed: Baric tablets (3 sets of different weights)

slides.setup_instructions: Lay all tablets on a mat. If DIY, use wood pieces of the same size but different density or weight.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to use our hands to feel WEIGHT. Close your eyes and hold this.' Place a heavy tablet in each hand, then a light one.
'Which one is heavier? Which is lighter? You can tell just by how they feel!'
Three-period lesson: 'This is light.' 'This is heavy.' 'This is medium — in between.' 'Show me the heavy one.'
Blindfold: 'Now sort WITHOUT looking. Feel each tablet and put it with others that weigh the same.'

slides.prompt: Sort all the tablets into three weight groups with the blindfold on. Check by looking when finished!

slides.text: 'Your hands can feel differences in weight! You sorted them perfectly using just your sense of touch.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sort tablets into three weight categories?

parent_notes: Baric tablets isolate the baric sense (sense of weight). The blindfold removes visual cues, forcing the child to rely entirely on the feeling of weight. If you don't have Montessori baric tablets, create DIY versions by filling identical small boxes or bags with different amounts of sand or rice. This work develops the same discrimination used when judging if a bag is too heavy to carry.

title: Moveable Alphabet — Short Vowel Words (e and o)
description: Focused work building CVC words with the short /e/ and /o/ vowel sounds using the moveable alphabet.
instructions:
1. Review the five vowel sounds: /a/, /e/, /i/, /o/, /u/.
2. Focus on /e/: build bed, red, pen, hen, ten, let, net, wet.
3. 'What sound do you hear in the MIDDLE of all these words? /e/!'
4. Focus on /o/: build dog, hot, mop, pot, log, top, box, fox.
5. Mix /e/ and /o/ words. Child builds from dictation.
6. Child reads all built words.

slides.setup_instructions: Open the moveable alphabet. Ensure plenty of vowel letters are available.

slides.text: Review vowels: 'a, e, i, o, u — the vowels! Every word needs at least one vowel.'
'/e/ words: listen — bed, red, pen. What sound is in the MIDDLE?' Build 'bed': /b/-/e/-/d/.
Build more /e/ words: red, pen, hen, ten, let, net, wet. Read each one!
Switch to /o/ words: dog, hot, mop, pot, log, top, box, fox. 'The middle sound is /o/!'

slides.prompt: I say a word, you build it! Mix /e/ and /o/ words: hot, pen, dog, red, mop, hen. Read them back!

slides.text: 'You are building words with ALL the short vowel sounds! /a/, /e/, /i/, /o/, /u/.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build and read CVC words with short /e/ and /o/?

parent_notes: Short vowel sounds are the trickiest part of early reading because they sound similar. /e/ and /i/ are often confused, as are /o/ and /u/. Focusing on one vowel at a time helps the child tune in to subtle differences. If the child confuses /e/ and /i/, exaggerate the sounds and use key words: '/e/ like in egg, /i/ like in itch.'

title: Linear Counting — Counting Chains of 10
description: The child counts a ten-bead chain, practicing counting to 10 with concrete beads. Introduction to the concept of skip counting.
instructions:
1. Present the short bead chain (chain of 10).
2. Lay it straight on the mat.
3. Count each bead: 1, 2, 3... 10.
4. Place an arrow label at 5 and at 10.
5. 'This chain has 10 beads. We can also count by fives: 5, 10!'
6. The child counts the chain independently and places the arrow labels.

slides.setup_instructions: Lay the chain straight on the mat. Have arrow labels in a small bowl.

slides.text: 'This is a bead chain! Let's stretch it out straight and count every single bead.'
Touch each bead: '1, 2, 3, 4, 5 — let's place the number 5 arrow here — 6, 7, 8, 9, 10!'
Place the arrow labels at 5 and 10. 'These arrows help us keep track.'
'We counted to 10! We can also skip count: 5... 10! That's counting by fives.'

slides.prompt: Count the chain yourself. Place the arrow at 5 and at 10. Then try counting backward: 10, 9, 8...

slides.text: 'You counted the chain of 10! Soon we will count even longer chains.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child count the 10-bead chain accurately and place arrow labels?

parent_notes: Bead chains are a beautiful Montessori material for linear counting and skip counting. The chain of 10 is the starting point. Arrow labels mark key numbers and build number line awareness. Later the child will count chains of 100 and even 1000! If you don't have bead chains, string 10 beads on a shoelace or make a paper bead chain.

title: Bean Seed Observation — Day Check
description: Checking on the bean seed planted last week. The child observes changes, draws what they see, and records observations in a simple science journal.
instructions:
1. Retrieve the bean seed cup from the windowsill.
2. 'Has anything changed since we planted it? Let's look carefully!'
3. Use a magnifying glass to observe the seed closely.
4. If sprouted: 'Look! A root is growing DOWN and a sprout is growing UP!'
5. Draw today's observation in a simple science journal.
6. Measure the sprout if possible. Water if the paper towel is drying out.
materials_needed: Bean seed cup from last week

slides.setup_instructions: Bring the seed cup and observation materials to the work area.

slides.text: 'Let's check on our bean seed! Remember, we are watching the life cycle happen in real time.'
Look closely with the magnifying glass. 'What do you see? Has the seed changed shape? Is anything growing?'
If sprouted: 'The root grows DOWN to find water. The sprout grows UP to find sunlight!'
'Let's draw what we see today. Scientists always record their observations.'

slides.prompt: Draw the bean seed as it looks today. Label what you see: seed, root, sprout. Is the paper towel still wet?

slides.text: 'We will keep checking every few days. Your seed is growing! Just like the boy's carrot seed.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe what has changed and draw an accurate observation?

parent_notes: Regular observation is the heart of scientific thinking. Even if the seed hasn't changed much, the child practices looking carefully and recording. Dates on each drawing create a simple growth record. If the seed hasn't sprouted yet, reassure the child that it can take 3-7 days. If it appears the seed has not been successful, plant a new one — gardeners always plant extras!

title: Printmaking — Sponge Stamp Prints
description: Creating prints using sponge stamps cut into simple shapes. The child learns to dip, press, and lift to create repeating patterns.
instructions:
1. Pre-cut sponges into simple shapes: circle, square, triangle, star.
2. Pour thin layers of tempera paint into shallow dishes.
3. Demonstrate: dip the sponge lightly, press onto paper, lift straight up.
4. Show how to create a pattern: circle, square, circle, square.
5. Child creates their own prints and patterns.
6. Try overlapping shapes and mixing colors.

slides.setup_instructions: Cut sponges into shapes beforehand. Pour thin layers of paint. Cover the table.

slides.text: 'Today we are making prints with sponge stamps! Look: a circle sponge, a square sponge, a triangle sponge.'
Demonstrate: dip the sponge flat side into the paint. 'Not too much paint!' Press onto paper. Lift straight up. 'A circle print!'
'Let's make a PATTERN! Circle, square, circle, square... What comes next?'

slides.prompt: Create your own stamp prints! Make patterns, pictures, or just explore. Try mixing shapes and colors.

slides.text: Let prints dry. Wash the sponges and clean up. 'You made beautiful patterns with prints!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create clear stamp prints and attempt a repeating pattern?

parent_notes: Sponge printing connects art with math (patterns) and sensorial work (shapes). The pattern-making extends the child's mathematical thinking — recognizing and creating repeating patterns is a foundational math skill. Let the child also stamp freely without patterns. Keep the paint thin so prints are crisp rather than blobby.

title: Polishing — Mirror or Metal
description: The child learns to polish a small mirror or metal object. This exercise teaches care for the environment, attention to detail, and the satisfaction of restoring shine.
instructions:
1. Place materials on a tray: small mirror or metal object, polishing paste or cream, soft cloth, cotton balls, small bowl of water.
2. Demonstrate: dip cotton ball in polish, apply in small circles.
3. Let the polish sit briefly.
4. Buff with the dry cloth using circular motions.
5. 'Look at the shine! Can you see your reflection?'
6. Child polishes independently. Clean up all materials.
materials_needed: Small mirror or metal object (brass, silver, or copper)
Metal polish or baking soda paste

slides.setup_instructions: Arrange all materials on a tray. Put on a smock. Choose a slightly tarnished piece for visible results.

slides.text: 'Look at this piece — it's a bit dull. We are going to make it SHINE! This is called polishing.'
Dip a cotton ball in the polish. 'Apply it in small circles. Cover the whole surface.'
Wait a moment, then take the dry cloth: 'Now we buff — rub in circles until it shines!'
'Look at the difference! One side is polished and one side is not. Can you see yourself in the shiny part?'

slides.prompt: Polish the entire piece. Work in small circles. Buff until you can see your reflection!

slides.text: Wash hands. Clean up all polishing materials. 'Beautiful work! You restored the shine.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete the polishing process: apply, wait, buff?

parent_notes: Polishing is a classic Montessori practical life exercise that teaches care for the environment. The before-and-after transformation is deeply satisfying. Use non-toxic polish or make your own with baking soda and water. Brass, copper, and silver pieces from thrift stores work perfectly. This work can be placed on a tray on the shelf for the child to repeat independently.

title: CVC Word Reading — Picture to Word Matching
description: The child reads CVC word cards and matches each to its corresponding picture card. Building reading fluency and comprehension.
instructions:
1. Lay out 8 picture cards (sun, hat, pig, cup, bed, log, pen, van).
2. Show word cards one at a time.
3. Child reads the word: '/s/-/u/-/n/ — sun!' and places it next to the matching picture.
4. Continue until all 8 are matched.
5. Check work by reading each pair.
6. Extension: child draws their own pictures for 3 new words.

slides.setup_instructions: Lay picture cards in two rows. Have word cards in a stack face down.

slides.text: 'Here are some pictures. And here are word cards. Your job is to READ each word and match it to its picture!'
Turn over the first word card. 'Sound it out: /s/-/u/-/n/. Sun! Which picture shows a sun?'
Child reads each card independently and places it beside the matching picture. Offer help only if the child is stuck.
After all are matched, read through each pair: 'Sun — yes! Hat — yes!' Celebrate correct matches.

slides.prompt: Match all 8 words to pictures. Then draw your own pictures for 3 new words: cat, box, rug.

slides.text: 'You read 8 words all by yourself! You are becoming a reader!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently read and match at least 6 out of 8 words?

parent_notes: Picture-word matching builds the connection between decoding (sounding out) and comprehension (understanding meaning). Watch the child's strategy — are they sounding out each word or beginning to recognize some by sight? Both strategies are developing. Make your own cards using index cards and simple drawings or magazine cutouts.

title: Golden Bead Introduction — Units, Tens, Hundreds
description: Introduction to the Montessori golden bead material. The child handles and names the three categories: unit bead, ten bar, and hundred square.
instructions:
1. Present one unit bead: 'This is ONE. One unit bead.'
2. Present a ten bar: 'This is TEN. Count the beads — ten beads all strung together.'
3. Present a hundred square: 'This is ONE HUNDRED. It's ten ten-bars put together!'
4. Three-period lesson: 'Show me ten. What is this? Give me one hundred.'
5. 'How many units in a ten?' (10) 'How many tens in a hundred?' (10)
6. Let the child handle and compare each freely.
materials_needed: Golden beads: units (loose beads), ten bars, hundred squares

slides.setup_instructions: Place each type on the tray, separated. Lay out a large work mat.

slides.text: Hold up one golden bead: 'This is a UNIT. One single bead. It represents the number one.'
Hold up a ten bar: 'This is a TEN BAR. Count the beads — there are ten beads strung together!'
Hold up a hundred square: 'This is a HUNDRED SQUARE! Feel how many beads. Ten bars put side by side make one hundred!'
Three-period lesson: 'This is a unit. Show me a ten bar. What is this?' (Hundred square!)

slides.prompt: Exchange! Trade me: 10 unit beads for 1 ten bar. Trade 10 ten bars for 1 hundred square. Count to make sure!

slides.text: 'Units, tens, hundreds — these golden beads help us understand big numbers! Next we'll use them together.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and distinguish unit beads, ten bars, and hundred squares?

parent_notes: The golden bead material is one of the most important Montessori math materials. It makes the decimal system tangible: the child can hold 1, feel the weight of 10, and appreciate the size of 100. The exchange game (10 units = 1 ten, 10 tens = 1 hundred) is the foundation for carrying in addition and regrouping in subtraction. If you don't have golden beads, use base-10 blocks (units cubes, ten rods, hundred flats).

title: Community Helpers — Introduction
description: Introduction to community helpers: people who work to help our community function. Exploring the roles of firefighters, doctors, teachers, and mail carriers.
instructions:
1. 'A community is all the people who live and work near us. Some people have jobs that help everyone!'
2. Show pictures of community helpers: firefighter, doctor, teacher, mail carrier.
3. Discuss each: 'What does a firefighter do? Why is their job important?'
4. 'What tools does each helper use?'
5. Sort picture cards by helper type.
6. 'Who are the helpers in YOUR community?'
materials_needed: Community helper picture cards or photos

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out helper cards. Have tool cards ready for matching activity.

slides.text: 'Many people work to help our community. Let's learn about some of them!'
Show firefighter: 'Firefighters put out fires and keep us safe. They use fire trucks, hoses, and special gear.'
Show doctor: 'Doctors help us when we are sick. They use stethoscopes and medicine.' Continue with teacher and mail carrier.
'Each helper has special TOOLS for their job.' Match tool cards to helpers.

slides.prompt: Match each tool to its community helper. Then draw a picture of yourself as a community helper. What would you be?

slides.text: 'Our community works because all these helpers do their jobs. We all help each other!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name at least 3 community helpers and describe what they do?

parent_notes: Community helper studies connect children to the real world and build social awareness. Point out helpers in your daily life: the crossing guard, the librarian, the bus driver. If possible, arrange visits or video calls with community helpers. Children's books about different occupations extend this learning beautifully.

title: Read-Aloud: Flower Garden by Eve Bunting
description: Reading 'Flower Garden' by Eve Bunting, a story about a child who creates a window box flower garden as a birthday surprise for her mother.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'What are they carrying? Where do you think they're going?'
2. Read the rhythmic text, pointing to the shopping and planting process.
3. Name the flowers: marigolds, pansies, daisies.
4. Discuss the surprise element: 'How do you think the mother will feel?'
5. Connect to our plant studies: 'What does the girl plant? What do plants need?'
6. 'Have you ever given someone a surprise?'

slides.setup_instructions: Sit together comfortably.

slides.text: Show the cover: 'A girl and her dad are carrying a box on the bus. What could be inside?'
Read with rhythm and warmth. Point out the progression: shopping, bus ride, planting, surprise.
After reading: 'The flower box was a birthday surprise! How did the mother feel?'

slides.prompt: 'What flowers would YOU plant in a window box? Draw your own flower garden and tell me about it.'

slides.text: 'Gardens can be anywhere — even in a window box! A garden made with love is a wonderful gift.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the sequence of events and connect to plant care knowledge?

parent_notes: This book beautifully shows urban gardening and the joy of giving. It continues the plant theme and adds an emotional/social dimension. The rhyming text is predictable and engaging. If you have space, create a small window box garden together — even herbs in a kitchen window count. This connects practical life, botany, and social-emotional learning.

title: Constructive Triangles — Second Box (Blue Triangles Without Lines)
description: Working with constructive triangles without black guiding lines. The child must figure out how to combine triangles to make shapes using only visual judgment.
instructions:
1. Present the second set of constructive triangles (no black lines).
2. 'Remember how triangles can make other shapes? This time there are no lines to guide you!'
3. Start with two right triangles. 'Can you make a rectangle?'
4. Try making a square from two triangles.
5. Try making a larger triangle from two smaller ones.
6. Challenge: create as many different shapes as possible.
materials_needed: Constructive Triangles — set without guide lines

slides.setup_instructions: Spread the triangles on the mat. Have the lined set nearby if the child needs to reference it.

slides.text: 'Last time, the black lines showed us where to join. This time, you have to figure it out with your EYES!'
Hand the child two right triangles: 'Can you make a rectangle? Try matching the long edges together.'
'Now make a square! And can you make a bigger triangle from two smaller ones?'
'What about a diamond shape? Or a hexagon? Experiment with different combinations.'

slides.prompt: Create as many different shapes as you can from triangles. Name each shape you make!

slides.text: 'You made shapes without any guide lines! Your eyes and hands knew what to do.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child form at least 3 shapes without guide lines?

parent_notes: Removing the guide lines adds a layer of challenge. The child must use spatial reasoning and visual judgment to determine which edges match. This progresses from concrete (with lines) to more abstract (without). If the child is frustrated, briefly show the lined version as a reference, then return to the unlined set. This work builds geometry intuition.

title: CVC Word Reading — Action Cards
description: The child reads CVC action words and performs the action. This multi-sensory approach connects reading to physical movement and comprehension.
instructions:
1. Write action words on cards: sit, hop, run, dig, hug, nod, tap, rub, pat, jog.
2. 'These words tell you to DO something. Read the word and then DO it!'
3. Child picks a card, reads it, and performs the action.
4. Continue through all cards.
5. Child makes their own action cards for family members.
6. Play 'Simon Says' using the cards.
materials_needed: Blank cards and marker for child to make their own

slides.setup_instructions: Write action words clearly on cards. Clear space for movement.

slides.text: 'Today reading is going to make us MOVE! Read the word and then DO what it says!'
Hold up 'hop': 'Sound it out: /h/-/o/-/p/. Hop! Now HOP!' Child hops.
Continue with: sit, run, dig, hug, nod, tap, rub, pat, jog. Act out each word!
'Reading tells us what to DO. Words have meaning — and these words mean ACTION!'

slides.prompt: Pick cards from the pile and do each action. Then make 3 new action word cards for your family to try!

slides.text: 'You read words and brought them to life! Reading is powerful — it tells us things!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read and act out at least 7 out of 10 action words?

parent_notes: Action reading cards are one of the most engaging Montessori reading activities. They prove to the child that reading has PURPOSE — the written word makes things happen! This is Montessori's concept of 'total reading' — connecting decoding to meaning. Make it a family game where everyone takes turns picking and performing cards. Children love being in charge of what adults do!

title: Golden Beads — Building Numbers (11-99)
description: Using golden beads and numeral cards to build two-digit numbers. The child combines ten bars and unit beads to represent numbers concretely.
instructions:
1. Review: unit = 1, ten bar = 10.
2. 'Let's build the number 23!' Place 2 ten bars and 3 unit beads.
3. Match with numeral cards: place the '20' card and the '3' card, overlapping to show '23.'
4. Build more: 15, 34, 47, 52, 68.
5. I say a number, child builds with beads AND cards.
6. Extension: child builds a number, I guess what it is.
materials_needed: Golden bead units and ten bars

slides.setup_instructions: Lay out ten bars and units in organized groups. Have numeral cards stacked by category.

slides.text: 'Today we are going to build bigger numbers! Let's start with 23. How many tens? TWO. How many units? THREE.'
Place 2 ten bars and 3 unit beads on the mat. 'Two tens and three units — twenty-three!'
Show the numeral cards: the '20' card and the '3' card. Overlay them: '23! The beads and the numbers match.'
'Let's build 47.' Child places 4 ten bars and 7 units. Finds '40' card and '7' card. Overlays: 47!

slides.prompt: Build these numbers with beads AND cards: 15, 34, 52, 68, 91. Then make up your own numbers for me to guess!

slides.text: 'You can build any number from 1 to 99 with golden beads! The beads SHOW the number.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child build at least 4 two-digit numbers with both beads and cards?

parent_notes: This lesson connects concrete quantity (beads) with the abstract symbol (numerals). The overlapping cards are key — the child sees that 23 is made of '20' plus '3.' This is place value made visible. Don't rush past this work; it builds the deep understanding needed for all multi-digit math. If you don't have golden beads, use base-10 blocks or even bundles of straws (10 straws bundled together = ten).

title: Flags — Drawing and Coloring
description: The child selects flags to study, draws them carefully, and colors them with the correct colors. Building cultural awareness and fine motor skills.
instructions:
1. Review flags from last week.
2. Present 3-4 new flags: France, India, South Africa, Australia.
3. Show each flag and name the country. Find it on the map.
4. Discuss colors and symbols: 'India has a wheel in the center. Australia has stars.'
5. Child selects 2 flags to draw and color carefully.
6. Label each flag with the country name.

slides.setup_instructions: Display flag cards. Have drawing materials ready. Open the world map.

slides.text: Review: 'Last week we learned about flags. What flags do you remember?' Show the old cards.
New flags: 'France has three vertical stripes: blue, white, red.' Find France on the map.
'India has three horizontal stripes: orange, white, green — with a blue wheel in the center!'
'Choose your two favorite flags to draw. Use a ruler for straight lines. Color carefully with the right colors.'

slides.prompt: Draw and color two flags. Try to make them look just like the real ones! Write the country name below each.

slides.text: 'Beautiful flags! Each flag tells us about a country's history and values.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child draw recognizable flags with correct colors and name the countries?

parent_notes: Flag drawing combines geography, art, and fine motor skills. The use of a ruler for straight lines develops precision. Don't expect perfect results — the effort and engagement matter. Start a flag collection book where the child adds new flags each week. This can become a yearlong project that the child takes pride in.

title: Watercolor — Painting a Sunset
description: Guided watercolor painting of a sunset using wet-on-wet technique. The child practices blending warm colors: red, orange, yellow.
instructions:
1. Show a picture of a sunset. 'What colors do you see?'
2. Wet the paper with the sponge.
3. Start at the top with red/dark orange. 'Paint across in gentle strokes.'
4. Below that, paint regular orange. Then yellow at the bottom.
5. 'Watch the colors blend where they meet! That's how sunsets look.'
6. When dry, optionally add a black silhouette (trees, mountains) with marker.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up painting area. Wet the paper. Have a sunset photo for reference.

slides.text: 'Sunsets have the most beautiful colors! Let's paint one. We'll start with the darkest color at the top.'
Wet the paper. Paint dark red/orange across the top with broad strokes.
Below that, paint bright orange. Below that, yellow. 'Watch the colors blend into each other!'

slides.prompt: Paint your own sunset! Let the colors blend on the wet paper. When dry, you can add tree silhouettes with black marker.

slides.text: Let dry. 'Your sunset is beautiful! Every sunset is different — just like your painting.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a blended warm-color painting?

parent_notes: A sunset painting is a wonderful guided project because it's almost impossible to 'fail' — blended warm colors naturally look beautiful. This builds confidence with watercolors. The optional silhouette (trees, hills) adds a second step and the contrast between flowing color and sharp lines. Frame this one — it makes a lovely gift!

title: Sewing — Stitching a Shape
description: The child sews along a simple shape (circle or heart) drawn on burlap, building on the running stitch learned last week.
instructions:
1. Draw a simple shape (circle, heart, or star) on the burlap with marker.
2. Thread the needle and tie a knot.
3. Child sews along the shape using the running stitch.
4. 'Follow the line! Up, down, up, down along the shape.'
5. When the shape is complete, tie off the thread.
6. The child may outline another shape with a different color yarn.

slides.setup_instructions: Draw a shape on the burlap. Thread the needle. Secure burlap in hoop if available.

slides.text: 'Last time you sewed a straight line. Today you will sew along a SHAPE! See the circle I drew?'
'Start at any point on the line. Use the running stitch: up, down, up, down. Follow the curve!'
'Curves are trickier than straight lines. Take small stitches around the curve for a smooth look.'

slides.prompt: Sew around the entire shape. When finished, try a second shape with a different color yarn!

slides.text: Tie off the thread. 'You sewed a shape! Your stitching is getting better and better.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sew along a curved shape with relatively even stitches?

parent_notes: Sewing curves is harder than straight lines because the child must adjust the needle direction. This builds spatial awareness. If the child finds curves too difficult, draw a square or triangle instead (straight edges). Save these sewing samples to track progress over time. Many children become deeply absorbed in sewing work — it is wonderfully meditative.

title: Phonetic Booklets — Reading Short Books
description: The child reads their first simple phonetic booklet — a tiny book with one CVC sentence per page and matching illustrations.
instructions:
1. Present a simple phonetic booklet (2-4 pages, one sentence each).
2. 'This is a little BOOK! You are going to read a whole book today!'
3. Page 1: child reads the sentence. Discuss the picture.
4. Continue through all pages.
5. 'You read a whole book!'
6. Child reads the book to a stuffed animal or family member.
materials_needed: Phonetic booklets or simple CVC readers (2-3 books)

slides.setup_instructions: Select books with CVC words and simple sentences. Sit together comfortably.

slides.text: 'Today is special — you are going to read a BOOK! A whole book, all by yourself.'
Open to page 1. 'Sound out each word. Take your time.' Child reads: 'The cat sat on a mat.'
Look at the picture. 'Does the picture match what you read? Yes! The cat IS sitting on a mat!'
Continue through each page. Offer help only if the child is truly stuck. Let them work it out.

slides.prompt: Read the book once more — this time to a stuffed animal or family member! You are the reader now!

slides.text: 'YOU READ A BOOK! You are a READER! This is just the beginning — there are so many books waiting for you.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read a simple phonetic booklet with CVC words?

parent_notes: Reading a first book is a major milestone — celebrate it! Phonetic booklets are specifically designed with only decodable words the child has learned. If you don't have Montessori phonetic booklets, look for Bob Books, Teach Your Monster to Read printable books, or make your own with simple sentences and drawings. Reading to others (a pet, a sibling, a stuffed animal) builds confidence and fluency.

title: Golden Beads — The Thousand Cube
description: Introduction to the thousand cube — completing the golden bead hierarchy. The child sees the progression from unit to ten to hundred to thousand.
instructions:
1. Review: unit bead, ten bar, hundred square.
2. 'What do you think comes next?' Reveal the thousand cube!
3. 'Ten hundred squares stacked together make ONE THOUSAND!'
4. Let the child hold and feel the weight.
5. Line up the progression: unit, ten bar, hundred square, thousand cube.
6. 'One, ten, one hundred, one THOUSAND!'

slides.setup_instructions: Have all four categories ready. Keep the thousand cube hidden for the reveal.

slides.text: Review the progression: 'One unit bead. One ten bar — that's 10 units. One hundred square — that's 10 tens.'
'The pattern is: each one is TEN times bigger! So what comes after a hundred? TEN hundreds!'
Reveal the thousand cube: 'This is ONE THOUSAND! Feel how heavy it is. That's 1000 beads!'
Line them up: unit, ten, hundred, thousand. 'See how they grow? 1, 10, 100, 1000!'

slides.prompt: Hold each one. Which is heaviest? Line them up from smallest to largest. Can you count: 1, 10, 100, 1000?

slides.text: 'One, ten, one hundred, one THOUSAND! You know the whole golden bead family!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name all four categories and order them from smallest to largest?

parent_notes: The thousand cube is awe-inspiring for young children. Its weight and size make 'one thousand' real. The progression from tiny unit bead to massive thousand cube demonstrates the power of our decimal system. Let the child handle the materials freely. Some children will want to count individual beads on the thousand cube — encourage this! It takes a long time and builds persistence.

title: Seasons — Winter and Spring
description: Exploring the characteristics of winter and spring. The child learns what happens in nature during these two seasons and compares them.
instructions:
1. Show pictures of winter scenes: snow, bare trees, animals hibernating.
2. 'In winter, it's cold. Trees lose leaves. Some animals sleep all winter — this is called hibernation.'
3. Show pictures of spring: flowers blooming, baby animals, rain.
4. 'In spring, it gets warmer. Flowers grow. Animals have babies.'
5. Sort picture cards into winter and spring categories.
6. 'Which season are we in right now?'

slides.setup_instructions: Set up two sorting areas labeled Winter and Spring. Spread picture cards face up.

slides.text: 'Our Earth has seasons — times of the year when the weather changes. Let's learn about WINTER first.'
Show winter pictures: 'Snow, cold, bare trees, short days, animals hibernating. Winter is a resting time.'
Show spring pictures: 'Rain, flowers blooming, baby birds, longer days. Spring is a waking-up time!'
'Winter and spring are very different! Let's sort these pictures.'

slides.prompt: Sort all the pictures into Winter and Spring. Then draw your favorite season. What do you like about it?

slides.text: 'After winter comes spring — cold turns to warm, and everything starts growing again!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe 3 characteristics of winter and 3 of spring?

parent_notes: Seasons are best taught through direct observation, so connect these lessons to what the child sees outside. 'The trees are bare right now — that's a sign of winter.' If you live in a place without dramatic seasons, use pictures and videos. The four seasons will be revisited multiple times throughout the year. A seasonal nature table that changes with the seasons makes this concrete.

title: Printmaking — Vegetable Stamps
description: Creating prints using cut vegetables. The child discovers the hidden patterns inside vegetables by using them as stamps.
instructions:
1. Cut vegetables in half to reveal cross-sections: bell pepper, celery bunch, mushroom, potato (cut a shape into it), corn cob.
2. Dip the flat cut side into tempera paint.
3. Press onto paper and lift — reveal the print!
4. 'Look at the star inside the pepper! The circles inside the celery!'
5. Create a vegetable print composition.
6. Label which vegetable made each print.

items: Halved vegetables: pepper, celery, mushroom, potato, corn
slides.setup_instructions: Cut vegetables before the lesson. Pour paint into shallow dishes. Cover the work area.

slides.text: 'Look inside this pepper — there's a star shape! And these celery stalks make circles! Vegetables have hidden patterns.'
Dip the flat side of the pepper into paint. Press it onto paper. Lift carefully. 'A flower shape!'
Try each vegetable. 'Which one makes the most interesting print? Are you surprised by any shapes?'

slides.prompt: Make prints with all the vegetables. Create a design or picture using the different shapes!

slides.text: 'Vegetables have beautiful hidden shapes inside them. Nature is full of art!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create clear vegetable prints and identify which vegetable made each print?

parent_notes: Vegetable printing combines art with nature observation. The cross-sections reveal patterns the child has never noticed: the star inside a pepper, the fractal pattern in broccoli, the circles in celery. This connects to botany and develops observational skills. Use vegetables that are past their prime — this is a great way to use up produce that's too old for eating.
